0.body: This book can be read online at https://bretzle.github.io/Embedded/ Sell your system! What can it do? How was it designed? What tools were used?

14.body: The DE10-Lite comes prequipped with 10 slide switches.
14.title: Overview

16.body: Nothing needs to be initialized. Simply read the memory itself or use the api calls.
16.title: Theory of Operation

17.body: The components is hardwired to the switches on the board
17.title: Hardware Connections

20.body: There are 10 LEDs that can be controlled on the board
20.title: Overview

21.body:
The component utilizes 10 bits, 1 for each LED. When a bit is high the LED will turn on. +-------+-----+-----+-------+-------+-------+
| LED 9 | ... | ... | LED 2 | LED 1 | LED 0 |
+-------+-----+-----+-------+-------+-------+
21.title: Memory Map

22.body: Nothing needs to be initialized. Simply read the memory itself or use the api calls.
22.title: Theory of Operation

23.body: The components is hardwired to the LEDs on the board
23.title: Hardware Connections

24.body:
write_leds(0x3FF); // Turns on all leds
write_leds(0x001); // Turns off all leds except the first
24.title: Testing and Usage

26.body: There are six seven-segment displays on the the DE10-Lite. Each display has its own decoder in hardware. These decoders support all hexadecimal characters.
26.title: Overview

27.body: Each decoder is 5 bits in memory where the first 4 are the digit to display and an enable bit. When the enable bit is set to 0 nothing will be displayed. Ex. +---+---+---+---+---+ | 1 | 0 | 0 | 1 | 1 | Would display 9 on the display +---+---+---+---+---+ ^----Data----^ ^ Enable bit +---+---+---+---+---+ | 1 | 0 | 0 | 1 | 0 | No display +---+---+---+---+---+
27.title: Memory Map

28.body: Nothing needs to be initialized. One can simply call the api's functions to write to each display.
28.breadcrumbs: Components » Seven Segment » Theory of Operation
28.title: Theory of Operation

29.body: The decoders are built into the system itself and are hardwired to the displays.
29.title: Hardware Connections

30.breadcrumbs: Components » Seven Segment » Testing and Usage
30.title: Testing and Usage

32.body: The system has two servo controllers that can control two independant hobby servo motors.
32.title: Overview

33.body: Each servo is effectivly an 8-bit register.
33.title: Memory Map

34.body: Nothing needs to be initialized in software. The value determines the position of the servo. Eacg servo has 90° of movement. When the register holds 0-200 the servo will move from 0-90°. If the value is >200 the servo will "turn off" (Allowing free range of motion) Internally the controller creates a pwm signal that will tell the servo the position to move to.
34.title: Theory of Operation

35.body: Each servo will require a connection to VCC (+5V), GND, and an arduino pin to drive.
35.title: Hardware Connections

36.body:
#include "servo.h" // Move the first servo to 45° and the second to 90°
move_servos_degree(45, 90);
36.title: Testing and Usage

38.body: The LCD component makes use of the LT24 Display. The display is 320x240 pixels and uses 16-bit color opposed to the traditional 24. The component makes use of Framebuffers in memory to handle pixel data.
38.title: Overview

39.body: The component allocates 150 KibiBytes on the heap when the framebuffers are initialized. This data must be freed after use.
39.title: Memory Map

40.body: The LCD will be automatically initialized when the system powers up. The display makes use of two framebuffers. The display has direct memory access to the frontbuffer. The buffers can be swapped by calling lcd_present. The display also supports touch interaction ( See components/touch ).
40.breadcrumbs: Components » LCD Display » Theory of Operation
40.title: Theory of Operation

41.body: The display uses the entire 40 pin GPIO Bus. More info can be found in the LT24 Datasheet
41.title: Hardware Connections

42.body: #include "lcd.h" lcd_init(); // initialize the framebuffer lcd_clear(); // clears the screen by setting every pixel to white lcd_draw_rectangle(0, 0, WIDTH, HEIGHT, RED); // draws a red line from (0,0) to (WIDTH, HEIGHT) lcd_present(); // swaps the framebuffers and draws changes lcd_free(); // Once done drawing free the framebuffers
42.breadcrumbs: Components » LCD Display » Testing and Usage
42.title: Testing and Usage

44.body: The LT24 LCD display is also a touch screen.
44.title: Overview

45.body: This component has a control register and a data register. Interacting with both of these should be done through the provided API.
45.title: Memory Map

46.body: The touch subsystem of the LCD utilizes an ADC as well as an SPI bus to communicate with that ADC. The LCD must be initialized via touch_init() prior to reading touch data.
46.breadcrumbs: Components » LCD Touch » Theory of Operation
46.title: Theory of Operation

47.body: This subsystem uses the same pins as the LCD display. See LCD Display documentation for more info
47.title: Hardware Connections

48.breadcrumbs: Components » LCD Touch » Testing and Usage
48.title: Testing and Usage

5.title: Overall Memory Map

50.body: An analog joystick similar to those found on game controllers. Allows vector based controls. Picture of joystick
50.title: Overview

52.body: The joystick makes use of a general purpose ADC. Vrx, Vry and Sw are connected to arduino ADC pins. Once the ADC is turned on the joystick inputs can be read by the system.
52.title: Theory of Operation

53.body: Name Direction Purpose Notes VCC out +5V connection GND out ground connection Vrx in Horizontal analog signal Connects to A0 Vry in Vertical analog signal Connects to A1 Sw in Clicking Switch Connects to A2 See DE10-Lite Manual for FPGA pins
53.title: Hardware Connections

54.body:
#include "analog.h" int32_t data[2]; analog_init();
get_analog_data(data); printf("X: %10d, Y: %10d\n", data[0], data[1]);
54.title: Testing and Usage

56.body: The accelerometer is a sensor build into the board that can detect movements on all 3 axes.
56.title: Overview

58.body: Internally the device uses an I2C bus to communicate with the rest of the system. The component must be initialized prior to retrieving data from the device. This device does not make use of interrupts.
58.title: Theory of Operation

59.body: Uses the accelerometer's pins more specifically: Name Direction Purpose G_SENSOR_SDO inout I2C address select G_SENSOR_SDI inout I2C serial data G_SENSOR_SCLK inout I2C serial clock G_SENSOR_CS_N out Enables I2C communication See DE10-Lite Manual for FPGA pins
59.title: Hardware Connections

8.body: The board comes equiped with two push buttons.
8.title: Overview

9.body:
Each button takes up 2 bits in memory. '1' is pressed. '0' is not pressed +----------+----------+
| Button 2 | Button 1 |
+----------+----------+
